senses.sense: to believe what someone says without any proof

senses.sense: used when adding a fact to something you have just said

senses.sense: used to refer to something or someone that can be seen or pointed to

senses.sense: used to refer to something that can be seen or pointed to

senses.sense: If you support or stay with someone through thick and thin, you support or stay with them in both easy and difficult situations.
senses.dict_examp: She'd stuck by Neil through thick and thin.
senses.lear_examp: As I had neither friends nor parents who could stand by me through thick and thin, this diary meant a lot to me.

senses.sense: the form of a verb or pronoun that is used when referring to the person or thing being spoken about or described

senses.dict_examp: I turned over a new leaf and began getting to work on time.
senses.lear_examp: She promised to turn over a new leaf.

senses.sense: to not accept something because you do not think it is good enough for you
senses.dict_examp: She turned up her nose at the job because she didn’t think it had enough status.
senses.lear_examp: Moreover, she will not turn her nose up at anybody who might be considered less worthy than her.

senses.sense: be unable to sleep properly
senses.dict_examp: I was tossing and turning for most of the night.
senses.lear_examp: As she tossed and turned, unable to sleep, she started going over the events that had taken place before that evening.

senses.sense: to return in the direction you have come from, or to make someone do this
senses.dict_examp: They had to turn back because of the bad weather.
senses.lear_examp: As we were walking along we came across a river we couldn't pass, so we turned back.

senses.sense: to reduce the level of sound or heat that something produces
senses.dict_examp: I asked him to turn down the heat.
senses.lear_examp: Actually, as I know nothing about instruments, the only thing I could do was just turn the volume up and down.

senses.sense: to refuse an offer or request
senses.dict_examp: He offered her a trip to Australia but she turned it/him down.
senses.lear_examp: I hope you don't turn down my invitation.

senses.sense: to change and become someone or something different, or to make someone or something do this
senses.dict_examp: The council was hoping to turn a children's home into a residence for adolescent girls.
senses.lear_examp: After midnight it turns into a club where you can dance to any kind of music.

senses.sense: to move the switch on a machine, light, etc. so that it stops working, or to stop the supply of water, electricity, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Have you turned the computer off?
senses.lear_examp: He turned the TV off and started thinking about Tania.

senses.sense: to move the switch on a machine, light, etc. so that it starts working, or to start the supply of water, electricity, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Ben turned the TV on.
senses.lear_examp: I turned the computer on to check my e-mail box.

senses.sense: to happen in a particular way or to have a particular result, especially an unexpected one
senses.dict_examp: The bomb warning turned out to be a false alarm.
senses.lear_examp: It was a very strange situation but turned out to be a good experience because we got know each other because of it.

senses.sense: to be known or discovered finally and surprisingly
senses.dict_examp: It turned out that we'd been to the same school.
senses.lear_examp: It turned out that Corey was organizing the concert and he asked me and three of my friends if we wanted to help.

senses.sense: If people turn out for an event, they go there.
senses.dict_examp: Thousands of people turned out to welcome the team home.
senses.lear_examp: On top of that, there were more than 5,000 people who had turned out for the festival!

senses.sense: to ask a person or organization for help or support
senses.dict_examp: Eventually she turned to her aunt for help.
senses.lear_examp: People were very friendly and there was always someone to turn to in case of trouble.

senses.sense: to arrive or appear somewhere
senses.dict_examp: Do you think many people will turn up?
senses.lear_examp: A few minutes later two security men turned up.

senses.sense: to increase the level of sound or heat that a machine produces
senses.dict_examp: Could you turn the heat up, please?
senses.lear_examp: But on the other hand they too do never turn their music up too much.

senses.sense: the time when you can or must do something, usually before or after someone else
senses.dict_examp: Is it my turn yet?
senses.lear_examp: I really enjoyed the holidays in England with you, so now it's my turn to invite you to come to my country, Peru.

senses.sense: a change in the direction in which you are moving or facing
senses.dict_examp: a left/right turn
senses.lear_examp: You need to take a right turn on the Main Street and walk toward the Public library.

senses.sense: When a number of people take turns, they do the same thing one after the other.
senses.dict_examp: We take turns to answer the phone.
senses.lear_examp: I suggest that each family takes turns to cut the grass once a week.

senses.sense: as a result of something that is part of a series of events
senses.dict_examp: This could result in the loss of certain species of fish and this in turn poses a serious threat to the fishing communities along the river banks.
senses.lear_examp: This, in turn, enabled them to find jobs and become financially independent from their husbands.

senses.sense: one after the other in an agreed order
senses.dict_examp: She spoke to each of the guests in turn.
senses.lear_examp: We had two different teachers in the mornings and in the afternoons, in turn.

senses.sense: a corner where one street meets another
senses.dict_examp: Take the first turn on the left.
senses.lear_examp: All you have to do now is to take the first turn on the left and after another 100 yards you will see the big building of a bank and I live right opposite.

senses.sense: to become better or worse suddenly
senses.dict_examp: The weather took a turn for the better.
senses.lear_examp: Despite all the environmental problems it is up to us to prevent things from taking a turn for the worse.

senses.sense: the start of a new century
senses.dict_examp: He was born at the turn of the century.

senses.sense: the way in which a situation develops, especially a sudden or unexpected change
senses.dict_examp: We were all shocked by this tragic turn of events.
senses.lear_examp: She was not prepared for such an unexpected turn of events!

senses.sense: someone who teaches one person or a very small group of people
senses.dict_examp: a private tutor
senses.lear_examp: Moreover, I worked in a kindergarden for two months and I was a tutor in a youth group for approximatly five years.

senses.sense: A turbulent situation, time, etc. is one in which there are a lot of sudden changes, arguments, or violence.
senses.dict_examp: a turbulent relationship
senses.lear_examp: We live in a turbulent time and people do not always have enough peace in their minds to question things.

senses.sense: the number 12
senses.dict_examp: ten, eleven, twelve, thirteen
senses.lear_examp: We can start at twelve o'clock.

senses.sense: a long passage under the ground or through a mountain
senses.dict_examp: The train went into the tunnel.
senses.lear_examp: Unfortunately, the tunnel was closed so I just had to continue walking on the pathway.

senses.sense: a series of musical notes that are pleasant to listen to
senses.dict_examp: That's a very catchy  tune.
senses.lear_examp: The song has a slow tune and the singer performs in a way that reveals his thoughts and his anxiety.

senses.sense: singing or playing the wrong notes
senses.dict_examp: The piano is out of tune.
senses.lear_examp: Even if you sing out of tune please call us.

senses.sense: singing or playing the right notes
senses.dict_examp: Try to stay in tune.
senses.lear_examp: The public was singing in tune with Jag, hands were raised and bodies were slowly swaying.

senses.sense: to understand what someone wants or needs or to understand a situation and act in a way that is suitable for it
senses.dict_examp: The congress is not in tune with the voters.
senses.lear_examp: I am not exactly in tune with all the latest trends but I know which styles give me the most satisfaction.

senses.sense: a situation in which there is a lot of trouble, confusion, or noise
senses.dict_examp: The whole region is in turmoil.
senses.lear_examp: Therefore, she finds herself in a state of confusion, as her feelings are in turmoil.

senses.sense: If you twist a part of your body, you injure it by turning it suddenly.
senses.dict_examp: I tripped and twisted my ankle.
senses.lear_examp: The worst part is, that we had an older lady within our group who had twisted her ankle so she was somewhat disabled at the time.

senses.sense: to turn something in a circle using your hand
senses.dict_examp: She sat there nervously twisting the ring around on her finger.

senses.sense: to turn part of your body to face a different direction
senses.dict_examp: She twisted around so she could see what was happening.
senses.lear_examp: Through the right side of the car I could see his eyes glitter like two flawless diamonds as he twisted his neck slightly from time to time to beam at me.

senses.sense: to change the meaning of something so that it fits what you want it to mean
senses.dict_examp: You keep twisting my words - that's not what I meant at all!
senses.lear_examp: Some members of the board twisted her words.

senses.sense: an unexpected change in a situation or in a story
senses.dict_examp: His promotion was just the latest twist in the story of his life.
senses.lear_examp: The plot takes several twists and turns till the conclusion which sums up the contents of the film.

senses.sense: the number 2
senses.dict_examp: They've got two houses.
senses.lear_examp: I go to college two days per week.

senses.sense: used to indicate a very small number, often no more than two
senses.dict_examp: We will spend a day or two in Boston.
senses.lear_examp: The thing you can do, is go out with your family first and than with your friends, or, you can ask your parents, if you can invite a friend or two to go with you.

senses.sense: to have difficulty making a decision
senses.dict_examp: I was of  two minds about whether to invite him to the wedding.

senses.sense: used for saying what usually happens
senses.dict_examp: Typically, a doctor will see about thirty patients a day.
senses.lear_examp: The climate of Brazil is typically tropical so the weather is gorgeous.

senses.sense: in a way that shows all the characteristics that you would expect from the stated person, thing or group
senses.dict_examp: She has that reserve and slight coldness of manner which is typically English.
senses.lear_examp: Your wife really made an effort to cook me typically English dishes.

senses.sense: a person or thing that is part of a group of people or things that have similar qualities, or a group of people or things that have similar qualities
senses.dict_examp: What type of house do they live in?
senses.lear_examp: Well, I think rock is the best type of music that we can put in the concert.

senses.sense: someone who has particular qualities or interests
senses.dict_examp: I can't quit now - I'm not that type of person.
senses.lear_examp: Usually these adults are the hardworking type and save money for the future.

senses.sense: the kind of person you find likable or attractive
senses.dict_examp: Grant’s the type of guy I like – strong and cool – but Willie’s not my type at all.
senses.lear_examp: It's true that he wasn't handsome, not at all the type she had used to prefer, but when he smiled, that wonderful smile that made his eyes sparkle, she realized, quite dazzled, that he was beautiful.

senses.sense: to write something using a keyboard
senses.dict_examp: She asked me to type a couple of letters.
senses.lear_examp: I'm typing this email to ask your permission to borrow your bicycle.

senses.sense: to use the keys on a computer or other device to enter information
senses.dict_examp: How can I type in my password if I can’t remember it?
senses.lear_examp: Unfortunately the phone was locked, so you had to type in a password to use the phone.

senses.sense: having all the qualities you expect a particular person, object, place, etc. to have
senses.dict_examp: I must look like the typical tourist with my shorts and my camera.
senses.lear_examp: If you want to go out at night there are good options for entertainment, for instance typical music shows.
